verses.verse: “Speak to the children of Israel, saying: ‘If anyone of you or your posterity is unclean because of a corpse, or is far away on a journey, he may still keep the LORD’s Passover.
On (2 Chr. 30:2, 15) the fourteenth day of the second month, at twilight, they may keep it. They shall (Ex. 12:8) eat it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
(Ex. 12:10) They shall leave none of it until morning, (Ex. 12:46; (John 19:36)) nor break one of its bones. (Ex. 12:43) According to all the ordinances of the Passover they shall keep it.

But the man who is clean and is not on a journey, and ceases to keep the Passover, that same person (Gen. 17:14; Ex. 12:15, 47) shall be cut off from among his people, because he (Num. 9:7) did not bring the offering of the LORD at its appointed time; that man shall (Num. 5:31) bear his sin.

‘And if a stranger dwells among you, and would keep the LORD’s Passover, he must do so according to the rite of the Passover and according to its ceremony; (Ex. 12:49; Lev. 24:22; Num. 15:15, 16, 29) you shall have one ordinance, both for the stranger and the native of the land.’ ”

(The Cloud and the Fire) Now (Ex. 40:33, 34; Neh. 9:12, 19; Ps. 78:14) on the day that the tabernacle was raised up, the cloud (Is. 4:5) covered the tabernacle, the tent of the Testimony; (Ex. 13:21, 22; 40:38) from evening until morning it was above the tabernacle like the appearance of fire.
So it was always: the cloud covered it by day, and the appearance of fire by night.

Whenever the cloud (Ex. 40:36-38; Num. 10:11, 12, 33, 34; Ps. 80:1) was taken up from above the tabernacle, after that the children of Israel would journey; and in the place where the cloud settled, there the children of Israel would pitch their tents.
At the command of the LORD the children of Israel would journey, and at the command of the LORD they would camp; (1 Cor. 10:1) as long as the cloud stayed above the tabernacle they remained encamped.
Even when the cloud continued long, many days above the tabernacle, the children of Israel (Num. 1:53; 3:8) kept the charge of the LORD and did not journey.
So it was, when the cloud was above the tabernacle a few days: according to the command of the LORD they would remain encamped, and according to the command of the LORD they would journey.

So it was, when the cloud remained only from evening until morning: when the cloud was taken up in the morning, then they would journey; whether by day or by night, whenever the cloud was taken up, they would journey.

Whether it was two days, a month, or a year that the cloud remained above the tabernacle, the children of Israel (Ex. 40:36, 37) would remain encamped and not journey; but when it was taken up, they would journey.
At the command of the LORD they remained encamped, and at the command of the LORD they journeyed; they (Num. 9:19) kept the charge of the LORD, at the command of the LORD by the hand of Moses.
(Two Silver Trumpets) And the LORD spoke to Moses, saying:
“Make two silver trumpets for yourself; you shall make them of hammered work; you shall use them for (Is. 1:13) calling the congregation and for directing the movement of the camps.
When (Jer. 4:5; Joel 2:15) they blow both of them, all the congregation shall gather before you at the door of the tabernacle of meeting.
But if they blow only one, then the leaders, the (Ex. 18:21; Num. 1:16; 7:2) heads of the divisions of Israel, shall gather to you.
When you sound the (Joel 2:1) advance, the camps that lie on the east side shall then begin their journey.
When you sound the advance the second time, then (Num. 2:3) the camps that lie (Num. 2:10) on the south side shall begin their journey; they shall sound the call for them to begin their journeys.
And when the assembly is to be gathered together, (Num. 10:3) you shall blow, but not (Joel 2:1) sound the advance.
(Num. 31:6; Josh. 6:4; 1 Chr. 15:24; 2 Chr. 13:12) The sons of Aaron, the priests, shall blow the trumpets; and these shall be to you as an ordinance forever throughout your generations.

(Num. 31:6; Josh. 6:5; 2 Chr. 13:14) “When you go to war in your land against the enemy who (Judg. 2:18; 4:3; 6:9; 10:8, 12) oppresses you, then you shall sound an alarm with the trumpets, and you will be (Gen. 8:1; Ps. 106:4) remembered before the LORD your God, and you will be saved from your enemies.

Also (Lev. 23:24; Num. 29:1; 1 Chr. 15:24; 2 Chr. 5:12; Ps. 81:3) in the day of your gladness, in your appointed feasts, and at the beginning of your months, you shall blow the trumpets over your burnt offerings and over the sacrifices of your peace offerings; and they shall be (Lev. 23:24; Num. 10:9) a memorial for you before your God: I am the LORD your God.”
(Departure from Sinai) Now it came to pass on the twentieth day of the second month, in the second year, that the cloud (Num. 9:17) was taken up from above the tabernacle of the Testimony.

And the children of Israel set out from (Ex. 19:1; Num. 1:1; 9:5) the Wilderness of Sinai on (Ex. 40:36) their journeys; then the cloud settled down in the (Gen. 21:21; Num. 12:16; Deut. 1:1) Wilderness of Paran.
So they started out for the first time (Num. 10:5, 6) according to the command of the LORD by the hand of Moses.
The standard of the camp of the children of Judah (Num. 2:3-9) set out first according to their armies; over their army was (Num. 1:7) Nahshon the son of Amminadab.
Over the army of the tribe of the children of Issachar was Nethanel the son of Zuar.
And over the army of the tribe of the children of Zebulun was Eliab the son of Helon.
Then (Num. 1:51) the tabernacle was taken down; and the sons of Gershon and the sons of Merari set out, (Num. 4:21-32; 7:7-9) carrying the tabernacle.
And (Num. 2:10-16) the standard of the camp of Reuben set out according to their armies; over their army was Elizur the son of Shedeur.
Over the army of the tribe of the children of Simeon was Shelumiel the son of Zurishaddai.
And over the army of the tribe of the children of Gad was Eliasaph the son of Deuel.
Then the Kohathites set out, carrying the (Num. 4:4-20; 7:9) holy things. (The tabernacle would be prepared for their arrival.)
And (Num. 2:18-24) the standard of the camp of the children of Ephraim set out according to their armies; over their army was Elishama the son of Ammihud.
